This song isn't directly about Apartheid, but about the Los Angeles Riots or Rodney King Riots in 1992. The rioters were mostly black and the Bloods and Crips called a truce during this period. The RKR started after footage was released of a motor driver who drove to fast, arrested and kicked and beaten by two police officers.
